awd_titl_txt: Extensions of Boundary Integro-Differential Operators and the Associated Computational Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will advance computer-based simulations for better process control and prediction in a wide range of applications; these include seismic imaging, petroleum engineering, electromagnetism in domains containing thin-wires, and molecular biology applications where molecular electrostatics energies are needed to understand the structure-function relations of proteins. The training of students in the proposed research areas, both through direct supervision of the PI or through the new graduate course to be developed, will allow them to conduct research in highly inter-disciplinary projects and bring state-of-the-art numerical analysis and computational algorithms to the related areas.

This research project will develop a general framework for formulating extension of a class of boundary integro-differential operators for numerical computation. The main advantage of the framework is that simple and accurate numerical algorithms can easily be designed on a variety of grid geometries and computational methodologies. The research will concentrate on (i) boundary integro-differential equations that arise from wave scattering problems in unbounded domains containing irregularly shaped scattering surfaces, and (ii) calculus of variation problems posed on manifolds of different codimensions. Regarding to (ii), minimization of convex energies and least-action principles defined on the manifolds will be considered. The minimization problems lead to elliptic equations on surfaces while the least-action principles lead to hyperbolic equations. A major focus will be on deriving extensions of these boundary operators "to the bulk", while preserving as much analytical properties (of the operators and of the solutions) as possible, using the additional degrees of freedom that come from the codimensions of the boundary. Concrete applications involving electromagnetic wave propagation coupled with thin-wires in space will be studied and simulated under the framework.

por.por_cntn:
This project involves the development of a mathematical framework and the corresponding numerical algorithms for two general classes of problems defined on nontrivial surfaces. The problems include solving differential or integral equations on nontrivial surfaces. They are found in a broad spectrum of applications, e.g., in wave scattering problems such as simulating radar signals being reflected by solid objects;  in petroleum engineering involving multiphase fluid problems; in molecular biology applications where electrostatics energies are needed to understand the structure-function relations of proteins.

The developed framework employs an essential idea of extending the original problems to a larger space that allows for existing robust  and accurate numerical methods to be applied seamlessly.
One of this project's main intellectual merits includes the advocated systematic approach, the derived extensions, and the mathematical theories. The PI has also published convincing computational results in a few different application areas. Such extensions reduce the need for painstakingly parametrizing the boundaries of very complex volumes, such as the volume occupied by large molecules or the surfaces sampled by LiDAR sensors.
Another intellectual merit is the proper treatments of "singularities," arising in the surfaces or the "laws of interactions" dictated by physics.
By exploiting special properties accompanying the extensions, the challenges of "singularities" may either be alleviated or completely avoided.  

This project has provided the training of three graduate students. Two of the graduate students obtained PhD degrees in 2019 and 2020 respectively. The project has also provided mentoring of two assistant professors, through collaboration.
